articles.title: Do the Right Things the Right Way
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Best practices often bring about policy compliance, yet policy compliance does not always deliver best practices. Basic cyber hygiene is the foundation of effective federal cybersecurity.
The People’s information is a priceless asset. The United States Government and its employees must ensure its integrity, confidentiality, and availability are expertly managed.

The Federal workforce is the Government’s first line of defense in protecting the People’s information. The desired target state is a culture where every employee recognizes the criticality of protecting the People’s information and their role in cyber risk management.

articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: In the past, most cybersecurity decisions were made in the server room. Today’s environment calls for informed decisions to be made at the right levels based on a clearly-articulated risk management construct.

content.micro:
Taking bold actions to protect Americans in today’s digital world. 

From buying products to running businesses to finding directions to communicating with the people we love, an online world has fundamentally reshaped our daily lives.  But just as the continually evolving digital age presents boundless opportunities for our economy, our businesses, and our people, it also presents a new generation of threats that we must adapt to meet.  Criminals, terrorists, and countries who wish to do us harm have all realized that attacking us online is often easier than attacking us in person.  As more and more sensitive data is stored online, the consequences of those attacks grow more significant each year.  

Meeting these new threats is necessary and within our grasp.  But it requires a bold reassessment of the way we approach security in the digital age.  If we’re going to be connected, we need to be protected.  We need to join together—Government, businesses, and individuals—to sustain the spirit that has always made America great. 

 The Cybersecurity National Action Plan (CNAP) is the capstone of more than seven years of determined effort, building upon lessons learned from cybersecurity trends, threats, and intrusions.  This plan directs the Federal Government to take bold action and fosters the conditions required for long-term improvements in our approach to cybersecurity across the Federal Government, the private sector, and our personal lives.

content.brief: If you believe you or your organization have been the victim of a cybersecurity incident, defined as a violation or imminent threat of violation of computer security policies, acceptable use policies, or standard security practices, please report the incident to National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center (NCCIC) through this reporting form.
If you believe you or your organization is the victim of ransomware, internet fraud, or other cybercrime, file a complaint with the Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) through this form.

content.micro: The resources below provide guidelines on how to handle cybersecurity incidents.

content.brief: Ready.gov is a national PSA designed to educate and empower Americans to prepare for and respond to emergencies. This resource includes information on what to do before, during, and after a cyber attack.

Pursuant to the Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA), each federal agency is required to notify and consult with US-CERT regarding information security incidents involving the information and information systems. Guidance for these notifications can be found here.

articles.title: NIST Computer Security Incident Handling Guide
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Recommendations of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) assisting organizations in establishing computer security incident response capabilities and handling incidents efficiently and effectively. This publication provides guidelines for incident handling, particularly for analyzing incident-related data and determining the appropriate response to each incident.

content.micro:
The Chief Information Security Officers (CISO) Council is the principal inter-agency forum uniting agencies’ efforts to strengthen the cybersecurity posture of the United States Government. 

The establishment of this council is currently underway, and additional details will be added to this site in 2017.

content.brief:
The CISO Council seeks to improve and enhance the cybersecurity posture of the United States by providing a government-wide forum that:

  • promoting the identification, development, and promotion of best practices;
  • instilling shared situational awareness and threat identification;
  • developing and promulgating information security policy;
  • improving strategic hiring and training of cybersecurity professionals;
  • encouraging implementation of shared services; and
  • providing professional development for cybersecurity professionals.

content.micro: Established by the Government Performance and Results Modernization Act (GPRA) of 2010, the Cross-Agency Priority (CAP) Goals aim to accelerate progress on a limited number of Presidential priority areas where implementation requires active collaboration between multiple agencies. OMB Cyber oversees and evaluates the implementation of the cybersecurity CAP Goal amongst the federal agencies. This CAP Goal has a mission statement of, “Improve cybersecurity performance through ongoing awareness of information security, vulnerabilities, and threats impacting the operating information environment, ensuring that only authorized users have access to resources and information; and the implementation of technologies and processes that reduce the risk of malware.”

content.brief: Performance.gov is a part of the Administration’s efforts to deliver a more effective, smarter, and leaner government through transparent reports and metrics which track agency progress towards meeting the CAP Goals.

content.micro: In accordance with the Federal Information Security Modernization Act of 2014 (FISMA), the annual report provides Congress and the public information on agency progress towards meeting cybersecurity performance goals and identifies areas in need of improvement. This report also provides information on Federal cybersecurity incidents, ongoing efforts to mitigate and prevent future incidents, and agencies’ progress in implementing cybersecurity policies and programs to protect their systems, networks, and data.

content.brief: This report covers agency cybersecurity performance throughout fiscal year 2014-2015.
